subtopics.par: About 15% is a good amount to set aside. This should be put into some sort of retirement account. Your objective with this is to lower your taxes.

list: Fixed / Necessary - food, rent, utilities, monthly payments
Variable / Discretionary - clothes, entertainment, and anything non-essential
Periodic - longer term expenses on the scale of quaters or years

subtopics.subheading: Hope for the best, plan for the worst.
subtopics.par: You should also have an emergency fund that can support you for 3-12 months in case something goes wrong

subtopics.subheading: When can you use your savings?
subtopics.par: Liquidity, in terms of finance, is defined as the ability to withdraw and use money. Higher liquidity is preferred, but it usually comes at the cost of lower interest rates. The money that you put in your retirement account often has low liquidity, but it pays off in the long run.
